; Mon, 30 Oct 2023 10:25:03 +0800 她研究在美中国本科留学生，发现高远志向下的挣扎和迷茫http://www.infzm.com/contents/259545
;;2023-10-30 09:00:00;
;

;;

;

;On May 17, 2022 local time, New York University graduates celebrated their graduation ceremony. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;The annual application season for international students is here again. According to the "2023 Study Abroad in China White Paper" released by New Oriental, more than 50% of people intend to study abroad with a bachelor's degree or below. The situation of studying abroad is picking up.

;

;At the same time, two other reports are also worthy of attention. On September 25, 2023, the National Student Credentials Certification Center in the United States released a report "Completing College" that showed that the undergraduate dropout rate for Chinese students in the United States was as high as 25%. In the same month, WholeRen, a Pennsylvania-based education consulting company, released the "2023 White Paper on the Current Situation of Chinese Students in the United States." According to statistics, 70% of Chinese students who have been dismissed from the United States are undergraduates, and more than half of the students are studying in the top 50 schools in the United States. The top two reasons for being dismissed were academic dishonesty and poor academic performance.

;

;;The data only presents the tip of the iceberg. In the seemingly distant American education system, many Chinese students are indeed experiencing struggles under the glamorous impression;. Ma Yingyi, a professor of sociology at Syracuse University in the United States, wrote the book "Ambitious and Anxious: The Success and Struggle of Chinese College Students in American Higher Education" (;;Ambitious and Anxious;;, ;;How Chinese College Students Succeed and Struggle in American Higher Education;;) ;, describes the status of Chinese students in the United States as "ambition and anxiety coexist."

;

;She found that whether they came from wealthy families or ordinary families, these international students began to experience this contradiction before arriving in the United States, and it intensified after entering college. They have big dreams, but in pursuing their dreams, they experience academic and social struggles and feel confused about their futures. They worry about whether they will be able to earn enough money after graduation to pay off their parents' investment in education.

;

;All this takes place against the background of the rapid development of Chinese society. All these anxieties forced them to think about the ultimate question: Is it really worth studying in the United States?

;

;The samples surveyed by Ma Yingyi included 507 Chinese international students from 50 American undergraduate colleges and universities, all born in the 1990s. The survey period was from 2011 to 2019. The book won the 2021 American Association for Comparative and International Education Higher Education Best Book Award and the American Sociological Association’s Bourdieu Book Honor Award. Recently, Ma Yingyi accepted an exclusive interview with Southern Weekend.

;

;;The increase in undergraduate international students is not due to the financial crisis;; ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;How did you pay attention to the group of Chinese international students in American undergraduate education? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;My research began in 2011. At that time, major universities in the United States began to have a large number of Chinese undergraduates. Prior to this, most Chinese students studying abroad in the 1980s and 1990s studied in China for graduate school and then went to the United States to study for Ph.D., or they completed their undergraduate studies in China and then went to the United States for graduate school, as was the case for me. Twenty years ago, I first came to the United States after earning my bachelor's degree in China. ;

;

;But around 2007, a large number of students came to the United States to study for undergraduates after completing high school in China, and some even went directly to the United States to study in high school.

;

;The difference is that most of the previous generation of international students either relied on scholarships from the United States to study for master's or doctoral degrees, or were sponsored by the Chinese government to study in the United States. As for the generation of undergraduates I follow, 90% are completely self-funded. For in-state students, tuition at public universities in the United States is very cheap, but international students have to pay extra, which is higher than out-of-state students, and private universities charge even more. Therefore, whether applying to public or private universities, the cost for Chinese international students is very high.

;

;In my opinion, this is a brand new phenomenon, reflecting the rise of the middle class and the accumulation of wealth in Chinese society. Then during the research process, I gradually discovered the duality of ambition and anxiety among this generation of international students. Whether it is academic or social life, or planning for the future, this contradiction is reflected.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Study abroad agencies on the market now recommend that parents study in the United States for their children Prepare for a huge cost of one million a year, which is higher than the cost in the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, Singapore and other regions. Why are there so many Chinese families willing to pay? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;The cost of undergraduate study in the United States may be the highest compared to other regions, so many people mistakenly believe that Chinese students studying in the United States They are all children of entrepreneurs, but in fact they are only a minority. ;

;

;In sociology, income and wealth are two different concepts. Income is your salary. Judging from income alone, China's middle class may not be able to afford tuition fees in the United States. But wealth is different. Wealth can include real estate, stocks, etc. In China, it is mainly real estate. Since the 2000s, China's urbanization has developed rapidly, the housing market has taken off, and many families who are not considered wealthy have also accumulated a certain amount of wealth.

;

;Among the samples I collected, some parents were middle school teachers, and some were even working-class parents. Because they own a house, they choose to liquidate this wealth to support their children's studies abroad.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What do teachers at American universities think of this change? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;I once met an administrator at Purdue University. He said that the school had a financial crisis after the 2008 financial crisis. It just so happened that Chinese undergraduates arrived at this time and had the ability to pay high tuition fees. He described it as a "perfect marriage." At that time, I discovered that this was a very systematic phenomenon, and there were not only needs from both parties behind it, so I started researching it. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The increase in international undergraduate students studying in the United States is due to the Financial crisis? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;Many people say that the increase in Chinese students came after the financial crisis in 2008, when American universities were short of money. But my survey data shows that the year with the highest annual growth rate in the number of Chinese students studying in the United States was 2007, before the financial crisis. Therefore, it is not the demand from American universities that has led to the rapid increase in Chinese students studying abroad, but more the demand from the Chinese middle class and above for their children’s education. ;

;

;At that time, China experienced rapid economic development, the rise of the middle class, and residents' income also increased rapidly. Another factor I mention in the book is the appreciation of the renminbi from 2006 to 2014. By 2014, the renminbi had appreciated by about 37%, making Chinese households more able to pay. On the other hand, it is still very difficult to get into good universities in China, and the United States is still the place with the largest concentration of good universities in the world, so many people come to the United States.

;

;;Three stages have "ambition and anxiety coexisting";

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;How did your research develop? How do you observe the "coexistence of ambition and anxiety"? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;My survey started in 2011. I initially used a sampling method to conduct an online survey, and then selected students who were willing to participate in in-depth interviews. We received 507 questionnaires from 50 institutions, and finally conducted in-depth interviews with 65 Chinese students who studied undergraduate in the United States from 2013 to 2016. I let students choose English or Chinese, and almost everyone speaks Chinese. Over the next three years, I conducted fieldwork in nine high schools in six cities in China and interviewed school counselors, principals, and teachers. ;

;

;I divide their experience into three stages. The first stage is before students come to the United States, they need to prepare for applications, exams, and school selection. The whole process is full of anxiety. This largely comes from their ambition, because they want to enter the top 30 or top 50 schools.

;

;The second stage is to choose a major. I have to choose a job that satisfies my interests and is easy to find a job. This is where conflicts with my parents begin to arise. They are also anxious during the social stage. Chinese students are very unfamiliar with American students’ social and entertainment methods, making it difficult to integrate. The purpose of many students going abroad is to get in touch with diverse cultures and different circles, so this also brings a lot of pressure and a sense of gap.

;

;The final stage is planning for the future. When I did my research, the job market was not what it is now, but there were all kinds of problems. For example, if you want to stay in the United States, you have visa issues. When you return to China, you have difficulty integrating into domestic circles, how to use domestic social capital, and how to choose a career. They are also eager to get satisfactory returns on their academic qualifications and experience.

;

;This duality of "ambition and anxiety" can be clearly observed in these three stages.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Compared with international students from other countries, Chinese students have this kind of Will duality be more prominent? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;Any international student will face this situation. Specifically, when it comes to Chinese students studying abroad, many of them sell their homes or take out loans to support their children studying abroad. Most of this generation are only children, and many of them need to return to their parents. ;

;

;Of course, from a philosophical perspective, ambition itself can generate anxiety. But Chinese international students are more prominent in this regard. During the writing process, I realized that to understand this generation of international students, it is actually very important to understand the Chinese society behind them.

;

;In the past two decades, Chinese society has actually been a state of coexistence of ambition and anxiety. No country has changed as much as China. People from all walks of life have felt many changes. Many people have achieved prosperity and many people have great aspirations and ambitions. People's horizons have broadened and their incomes have increased. At the same time, they are always worried about what opportunities they have missed. They are eager to gain an international perspective, but this requires a lot of resources. People have also begun to worry about whether their investment can obtain sufficient returns. All this brings Come to anxiety.

;

;The same is naturally true for Chinese students coming from this environment. Moreover, international students are not a random group of people in any society. They are a group of people with ambitions and certain privileges. Sociologically speaking, migrant populations are more ambitious and goal-oriented than migrant populations. International students want to study to get a degree and see the wider world. They even bear the expectations and eyes of the entire family, and bear the pressure and opportunities brought about by social changes. Opportunities and challenges coexist.

;

;On the other hand, although China's society has undergone tremendous changes, education has not changed that much. The main reason is that the college entrance examination is still the baton. The primary and secondary education received by Chinese children and American children is very different. Chinese students go to American higher education with the imprint of Chinese education. This change itself also brings great challenges to them.

;

;In short, Chinese international students may be the group with the most "dual nature of ambition and anxiety" among the international student groups in the world, or among the floating population.

;

;;

;

;Left: "Ambition and Worry: The Successes and Struggles of Chinese College Students in American Higher Education." Right: Ma Yingyi, professor of sociology at Syracuse University, USA. ;(data map/picture);

;

;;Encountering a "sense of gap";

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You also mentioned in your book that after some Chinese students come to the United States, they will be troubled because their school is in a "village" Shock? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;The most famous case is the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, which everyone says is a cornfield. ;

;

;This has a lot to do with the history of the development of higher education in China and the United States. Chinese universities are concentrated in big cities, while in the United States there are actually not many big cities, but there are many university towns, which are schools built in large rural areas.

;

;Each state has its own flagship school, and the top QS-ranked schools are not necessarily in big cities. Of course, university rankings are one-sided and easily misleading information. Universities in the United States are very diverse. There are very good academic colleges and community colleges in public schools. Different schools have different missions. They are not strictly superior or inferior.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Why do international students value university rankings so much? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi: ;;One reason is that the admissions system in the United States is very different. It does not only look at scores. You don’t know what proportion the scores will account for. , there is no way to quantitatively determine whether it is 10%, 5%, or 90%. Every school is different, every major is different, and every school is different in different years. No one will tell you. ;

;

;American students may choose this school for various reasons such as good results in a certain sport, the school being close to home, or even the beautiful scenery. But Chinese students don’t understand this, and university rankings have become a source of stress and anxiety for them.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Among your interviewees, this "sense of gap" still exists In what ways does it appear? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;The sense of gap in life, including interpersonal communication. They may have thought Americans were warm and open, but later discovered that making friends was not as easy as they thought. For example, some students were ambitious at first and hoped to make many American friends, but they were quickly frustrated. A very important way of social entertainment for American college students is weekend parties. Many people at the party drink and play some drinking games, such as putting a ping pong ball on a beer bottle and everyone blows it together. Whoever the ball hits gets a drink. . Many Chinese children cannot join in, and many find drinking games unbearable. ;

;

;Many people feel frustrated and return to the circle of Chinese students. The entertainment in this circle may be eating together, singing at KTV, girls going shopping, and boys playing games. Many Chinese students will feel that I should not hang out with Chinese people when I go abroad. Their parents will even urge them to make American friends, saying, "If you don't make American friends, your English will not be as good as before you went abroad."

;

;There is a Chinese student who speaks English very well, is outgoing, and has many American friends. Everyone thinks he grew up in the United States. However, after he integrated into the circle of American college students, he was disappointed. He did not enjoy the multiculturalism as he had imagined before, so he returned to the circle of Chinese people, assuming leadership positions in the Chinese international student group and hosting the Spring Festival Gala.

;

;I think this is a very interesting return. I went out for a while, had my imagination shattered, and then came back. In a philosophical sense, this return is a process of finding oneself. Although he finally returned to the Chinese students, he came out to see, interact with, and experience a different world, which was different from the one he had originally The state of not going out is completely different.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;How do they adapt to this "sense of gap"? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;This sense of gap will affect their satisfaction with studying abroad and will affect their entire state, including study, social interaction, daily life, etc. , in fact, it is difficult to adapt. But time itself brings habits, and students who have never been accustomed to it may choose to leave. For example, some students' undergraduate schools are in large rural areas in the United States. After graduation, they will apply to study for graduate students in big cities such as New York and Boston. . ;

;

;In short, you still need to deepen your understanding of yourself and the new environment. Before studying abroad, you should first understand what you really want, what the school can provide, and try to reduce some misunderstandings. Only in this way can you reduce the problems caused by misunderstandings in the future. Come with dissatisfaction and anxiety.

;

;It is very beneficial to make some preparations to adapt to the environment. For example, a student whose family conditions are relatively good, his parents found him an American friend on Twitter to accompany him to practice speaking, communicate and communicate with him. Some students will go to American schools in advance to adapt to the environment. I also did some statistical analysis and found that participating in more club activities, participating in school organizations, etc. can improve students' satisfaction with studying abroad.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;In addition to daily life, international students do not speak in class and it is difficult to integrate well Classroom and academic activities have actually always been a problem. ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi: ;;They may really want to express themselves and participate, but it is difficult for them to participate. This situation of not getting what you want actually brings a lot of psychological burden. ;

;

;I have personal experience with classroom discussions. I often ask my classmates to discuss in class. Discussions are not entirely a challenge to English communication. Language is the most basic threshold. Many students who are very good at English also find it difficult to participate in discussions. My survey shows that 60% of students think that their English is very good, but only 20%-30% of all students think that they often speak in class.

;

;What factors are holding them back? I think a very important reason is the difference in basic thinking patterns, and students cannot express themselves bravely and fully. Most Chinese classrooms are always looking for standard answers, and students are always worried about whether what they say is right. In contrast, American university classes are open-ended discussions with no right answers. This is a considerable difference. Chinese students need to change their thinking patterns to participate effectively in discussions.

;

;;Leverage strengths and avoid weaknesses, rather than make up for gaps;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;This book was published in 2020. In the following three years, we have all experienced more changes. Have you observed any new situations?  ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;International students all over the world are having a difficult time during the COVID-19 epidemic. It is inconvenient to travel and they are far away from their families. It should be said that Chinese international students are in a worse situation. difficulty. My basic conclusion has not changed, but these three years have clearly made "worrying" worse. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;How do you understand "worried"? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;The specific challenge is uncertainty, which is reflected in all aspects of studying abroad. When will flights be added? Would it be easier to return home? Why are student visas and work visas so difficult to apply for? U.S. policies and public opinion trends will increase the psychological pressure on Chinese students. This is a pressure that Chinese students did not have 10 years ago. ;

;

;In addition, when I wrote this book, there seemed to be a very consistent tendency to choose the United States, but now many students have chosen Europe, Japan, including Hong Kong, China, etc. This is a relatively big change. . Recently released data shows that the number of Indian students in the United States has exceeded that of Chinese students.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What do you think of the trend of younger students studying abroad? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi:;;More and more families are choosing to send their young children to study abroad. This may be due to structural reasons. ;

;

;In the elimination system of standardized tests, most people are not winners. Although some students have become winners, in this competitive environment, they are unable to obtain a more balanced physical and mental development, or they are unhappy.

;

;So many families choose to study abroad at a young age. Obviously everyone knows that there are risks. Compared with college students, the risks are higher. However, after analyzing the risks and rewards, they feel that the benefits outweigh the disadvantages, so they make the decision. This choice.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What suggestions do you have for Chinese international students and parents? ;

;

;;Ma Yingyi: ;;The most important thing is to learn more about yourself through various methods. For example, through parents, friends, or by participating in various activities to understand yourself more comprehensively. Studying abroad actually just opens a window. After arriving, you have to make many choices, including which courses to take, which societies to join, what future path to choose, etc. ;

;

;A great advantage of American higher education is that it provides many choices. For a person to make a choice that suits him or her, a very important prerequisite is self-awareness. So you need to understand yourself, what your strengths are, what your weaknesses are, what you are passionate about, and what abilities you cannot develop. One person cannot be good at everything. The most important thing in modern society is to do things that you are good at and interested in.

;

;It doesn’t matter if you don’t know yourself well. I think this is a lifelong lesson. But students should have this awareness now, and start focusing on their own interests and strengths from now on, making use of their strengths and avoiding weaknesses, rather than making up for gaps. I think both students and parents need to make adjustments in their thinking.

; Mon, 30 Oct 2023 09:25:03 +0800 巴以舆论战开打，以色列缘何撤销公共外交部？丨智库视点http://www.infzm.com/contents/259553
;;2023-10-30 08:00:00;
;

;On October 22, 2023 local time, the Israeli cabinet decided to revoke the country’s main responsibility for public diplomacy through a telephone vote. , the Ministry of Information for External Propaganda Affairs (generally referred to as the "Public Ministry of Foreign Affairs" in news reports), and said that the ministry's budget will be transferred to the recovery and reconstruction of communities around the Gaza Strip.

;

;This is a gesture by the Israeli government directed at both its domestic public and the international community.

;

;Abolish the so-called inaction departments internally, find scapegoats, and try to homogenize domestic public opinion. It has demonstrated its determination to burn its boats to the outside world, and any attempt by the outside world to interfere with Israel's will will be rejected.

;

;What does the dissolution of the Ministry of Public Affairs mean?

;

;The term "public diplomacy" was first proposed by Professor Edmund Glean of Tufts University in the United States in 1965. He believed that public diplomacy is to ensure that one's own country maintains effective relations with foreign countries. Thought connection”. More generally speaking, public diplomacy is a strategic plan to carry out national marketing and create a positive and good international image. It is a "popular project" to win the hearts and minds of the international people.

;

;This time, Israel directly announced the immediate dissolution of the Ministry of Public Affairs. It is obvious that it has deeply felt the changes in international public opinion. Israel’s external propaganda department cannot escape the blame for this, although Israel is doing a positive job The battlefield has an overwhelming advantage, but the corresponding situation is not shown on the battlefield of public opinion. The reasons behind this are worthy of scrutiny.

;

;First of all, global public opinion has embarrassed Israel, which not only seriously interferes with Israel's upcoming retaliatory actions, but also has the potential to further weaken Israel's internal unity.

;

;In this atmosphere, Minister of Public Foreign Affairs Atbaryan's voluntary resignation not only gave herself a step down, but also showed her support for the Netanyahu government. She said, "Put aside Self-deprecation aside, running a ministry in such a horrific time of war is an expensive problem and the Israeli people need every shekel.”

;

;On October 12, the latest opinion poll conducted by the "Jerusalem Post" showed that nearly four-fifths of the people believe that the Netanyahu government needs to deal with this large-scale Hamas infiltration and Responsible for the massacre of Jews, the Israeli government must not only unite internally and externally at this moment, but also consider a potential post-war political reckoning.

;

;Secondly, Israel’s internal struggles remain complex and changeable, which has profoundly affected Israel’s security environment.

;

;Israeli media pointed out that the Ministry of Public Affairs not only failed to fulfill its obligations, but even interfered in Israel's internal affairs for a long period of time. This minister from the Likud Party has used his power to vigorously promote the government's judicial reform and made a series of inflammatory remarks. For example, in April 2023, Atbaryan directly pointed out that the military, police and media composed of The deep state network is working hard to overthrow the government, which is reminiscent of how the Turkish government described the Gulen movement before the attempted coup in 2016, highlighting that the Israeli state and society are gradually being torn apart. In addition, she has launched scar-revealing attacks on her political critics, underscoring her right-wing conservative ultra-hardline political stance, which runs counter to Israel's desire to be diplomatic in its international propaganda matters.

;

;In fact, on October 12, before the department was disintegrated, she issued a resignation statement, saying that the power of her department had been weakened, and there was an overlap of powers between the Ministry of Expatriate Affairs and the Ministry of Public Affairs. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs only received its budget six months after the new government was formed.

;

;This is the first cabinet member to resign after a new round of conflict between Palestine and Israel broke out. This is just a microcosm of Israel’s domestic struggle.

;

;This Palestinian-Israeli conflict, analyzed only from a technical level and from an absolutely neutral political stance, has greatly shocked Israel. It is comparable in form to the Fourth Middle East War and in terms of psychological trauma. Compared with the "9·11" incident in the United States. This is not unrelated to the division of domestic public opinion caused by Israel's promotion of judicial reform in the past year. The root cause is the long-standing dispute between left and right, religious and secular disputes in Israel's internal affairs, as well as the frequent changes of governments in recent years. hidden fundamental crisis.

;

;As the saying goes, fortresses are breached from within. Israel’s recent political chaos has seriously affected its military and intelligence systems, giving Hamas room to take advantage of the situation. In addition, the peace process between Israel and Saudi Arabia About to enter its final chapter, Hamas urgently needs to give the international community a heavy blow and prove to the world that Middle East reconciliation that bypasses the Palestinian-Israeli issue is putting the cart before the horse.

;

;Finally, the dissolution of the Ministry of Public Affairs heralds the imminence of a larger-scale bloody operation. Israel is consolidating all resources and preparing for war. Israel's domestic thinking in fighting Palestine urgently needs to form a united front.

;

;Israel’s move is also preparing for the worst for the safety of the hostages, that is, it ignores the hostage weight in the hands of Hamas, ignores domestic and foreign voices in favor of reconciliation negotiations, and treats Hamas the possibility of a complete liquidation. But this is undoubtedly a difficult decision. Hundreds of thousands of soldiers on the Israeli border are hesitant. During Biden's visit, he issued "Advice to Israel" and so on. These all prove that the large-scale ground war against Gaza will not only affect Israel's The international image is more likely to cause further division within Israel.

;

;The situation on the battlefield of public opinion is tense

;

;As a medium for public diplomacy and a window for understanding the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, the importance of public opinion is self-evident. With the many conflicts that have broken out in recent years Similarly, the public opinion field is the second battlefield opened by all parties.

;

;Today, various advanced technological means, such as 5G, streaming media, artificial intelligence and mobile-based social media networks, have made the battlefield of public opinion mixed, making it difficult to distinguish between true and false, and the situation is changing rapidly, which has brought about The "information tide" has a strong ability to induce and differentiate positions and values ​​and create opposing emotions for the public who lack certain professional knowledge.

;

;Looking at the public opinion war in this Palestinian-Israeli conflict, it has the following three major characteristics.

;

;First of all, the mature development of streaming media and online live broadcast technology has given global audiences a stronger audio-visual impact on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. The timeliness and impact of information dissemination have greatly increased, and it has also provided opportunities for the proliferation of false information. It has provided a breeding ground for various conspiracy theories, historical-realistic information confusion and propaganda, and fake accounts and robot trolls have emerged one after another on social media. While expanding attention, it has also set off a confrontation between the two factions around the world. These include positional opposition (supporting Israel or supporting Pakistan), religious opposition (Judaism and Islam), ethnic opposition (Arabs and Jews), and intra-sect opposition (moderate factions exist within both Arabs and Jews).

;

;When Hamas launched its attack, it used heavy bulldozers to break through the Gaza separation wall and carry out bloody killings inside the Israeli border posts. The video was broadcast live on the Internet. This video set off a new wave of sectarianism in the Arab world. , nationalistic sentiments, but also directly angered groups sympathetic to Jews. It is precisely because of the popularity of the Internet and mobile devices that war has achieved a certain form of visibility and transparency, and has become a hotbed and soil for breeding public opinion wars.

;

;Secondly, when the Western media reported on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, the wording was the Israel-Hamas War, not the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. This highlights the asymmetric nature of the conflict and is a precautionary endorsement of a potential high-intensity Israeli military strike. Hidden behind this is the challenge to the loopholes in international law and the laws of war. Because the laws of war are applicable to sovereign states, the Israeli Defense Forces' attack on Hamas is most likely to be a "police-like war." Such a narrative will also separate the public from the perspective of ethnic and religious conflicts. The legitimacy of the war on terrorism is obviously greater than the battle for territory. It can be seen that the inclusion of stance in narrative strategies is an eternal pattern.

;

;Thirdly, the public opinion war in this conflict has typical sinking and spillover effects. This conflict has transcended the conflicts between Palestine and Israel and Kazakhstan and Israel, and has shown a trend of spillover and camp formation. Currently, both sides are working hard to seek legitimacy for the war, and have moved from the level of international authoritative media to the level of mass entertainment media. The two sides are competing for the right to speak across the air in other countries. This is not common in previous war conflicts, but it is inevitable for the vigorous development of modern information technology.

;

;Finally, after Israel announced the dissolution of its Public Ministry of Foreign Affairs, it has in a sense reaped the consequences.

;

;On October 24, Hamas publicly released two old Israeli women. A video of them shaking hands with masked Hamas members and saying goodbye went viral on social platforms, and they later faced dozens of reporters. , the released elderly people said that Hamas treated them very friendly and responded to their requests. The accounts of those who have witnessed it are extremely impactful, which has compressed the public opinion space in Israel now and even for a long time in the future, and also caused doubts in the Israeli media.

;

;The game between Palestine and Israel has never stopped when narrating the war. The mutual siege is not only a portrayal of the real battlefield, but also a manifestation of online public opinion. This is a microcosm of the structural contradiction between Palestine and Israel in the field of international political communication.

;

;In recent years, female-themed works have exploded, but most of them Focusing on the plight of urban women, there are still very few films with small town women as protagonists.

;

;"Stone Gate", which was recently released on streaming media, is a precious image of the latter.

;

;;

;

;01;

;The directors of "Stone Gate" are rising independent film stars Huang Ji and Otsuka Ryuji, who are a husband-and-wife team. The two co-produced the "Women's Trilogy" "Eggs and Stones", "Stupid Bird" and this "Stone Gate".

;

;;

;

;Born in Hunan In the small town, Huang Ji's perspective mainly focuses on the survival plight of rural women.

;

;"Eggs and Stones" focuses on the left-behind girls who were sexually assaulted.

;

;;

;

;"Stupid Bird" "Through the carrier of "mobile phone", it shows the growing confusion of left-behind girls.

;

;;

;

;"Stone Gate" It takes the experiences of female college student Lin Sen as a slice to reflect reality.

;

;The ages of the heroines in the trilogy are consistent, they are 14, 17 and 20 years old respectively, and the same actor Yao Honggui was chosen.

;

;In contrast, "Stone Gate" is more mature than the previous two films. The film style is very similar to the early works of domestic sixth-generation directors that we are familiar with. It uses non-professional actors, talks about marginalized groups, and prefers extreme Life-like scenes and an objective and calm perspective.

;

;;

;

;But on the kernel , with Huang Ji’s own characteristics and personal experience, his friend and work partner Otsuka Ryuji can also make some observations about the film.

;

;02

;

;The narrative of "Stone Gate" relies on the three identities of a 20-year-old girl.

;

;First of all, she is Lin Sen, a beautiful female college student, studying as a flight attendant at a vocational school. She has a stable relationship with her boyfriend Liu Long, who even paid for her to enroll in an English training class. With the unexpected pregnancy, Lin Sen's life also changed.

;

;;

;

;Lin Sen's My parents run a small clinic. The father is disabled, the mother is addicted to micro-business, and a medical accident that caused a female patient to miscarry made the family worse.

;

;;

;

;Sensible Lin In order to help his family pay off debts, Sen started working crazily to earn money. She worked as an opening welcome model and also went to shopping malls to sell milk powder.

;

;;

;

;Unexpected pregnancy and Family debt caused Lin Sen's originally peaceful life to plummet.

;

;Lin Sen has no intention of becoming a mother, her boyfriend cannot be held responsible, and her creditor wants a child. With the help of her parents, she agreed to an incredible plan to give birth to a child to pay off the debt to the poor woman "Yinfang" who unfortunately had a miscarriage.

;

;Pregnancy is a unique life experience for women. The difficulties unmarried young women face when they have an unexpected pregnancy, whether to have an abortion or not, are common themes in feminist films.

;

;The Romanian film "April, Three Weeks and Two Days" and the French film "As It Happens" are both set in the last century when abortion was not accepted by most countries. Due to the complex social status quo, women Uterine autonomy is often not possible.

;

;;

;

;American movie " "Juno" and the Norwegian film "Ninja Babies" focus on the physical changes and mental stress that pregnancy and childbirth bring to women.

;

;;

;

;In domestic movies , Li Yu's "Beautiful Beauty" also reproduces the various pressures faced by women after unexpected pregnancy, mainly due to the relatively conservative social public opinion environment.

;

;The difference in "Stone Gate" lies in the alternative way of handling the heroine Lin Sen's pregnancy - not having an abortion but abandoning her for adoption. ‍‍‍‍‍‍Children are also used as a commodity to solve her immediate life problems. ‍‍‍‍‍

;

;On the surface, this is Lin Sen’s active choice, but the film also pays attention to the soft coercion she suffered. ‍

;

;Just like at the beginning of the film, her boyfriend took her to an English speaking training venue. Others were communicating freely, and the topic revolved around the country they wanted to go to. After Lin Sen found that she couldn’t fit in, she went to the Start playing with your phone on the sofa. She has no strong desire to improve her English. She came here because her boyfriend took the initiative to make the choice for her.

;

;;

;

;‍This one , we can clearly feel the girl Lin Sen's numbness towards life and new life, the lack of vitality and confusion.

;

;The high frequency of static shots in the film further exaggerates this sense of silent despair. ‍

;

;;

;

;Lin Sen She rarely showed her emotions. Even when her boyfriend asked for an abortion, she didn't make a fuss.

;

;But the pain in her breasts during pregnancy and the tearing during childbirth, as well as Lin Sen’s unbearable expression and voice, tell us that her pain is indeed real.

;

;;

;

;In pain and In confusion, she gradually lost control of her destiny.

;

;03

;

;The plot of "Stone Gate" is not complicated, but the film is 147 minutes long because the director placed many shots on the social landscape.

;

;In many scenes, Lin Sen does not participate in the main narrative, appearing as a background board and becoming a silent observer. ‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍

;

;For example, she would watch her boyfriend shoot a Douyin wedding promotional video, and watch underground industry managers openly interview young girls.

;

;;

;

;Lin Sen’s mother Obsessed with selling three-no products and telling his story at the organization's annual meeting. ‍‍

;

;;

;

;Outbreak Later, crowds of people gathered at medical equipment institutions to buy medical masks.

;

;;

;

;This is " The biggest feature of "Stone Gate" is also the film's problem. On the one hand, the unrestrained display of shots greatly affects the rhythm of the narrative, and too many idle strokes make the movie long and boring. On the other hand, it also leads to the heroine becoming a tool, making the entire story biased towards curiosity and lacking the power to move people's hearts.

;

;Although film and television works showing women in small towns have been relatively scarce in recent years, they were not uncommon in previous years.

;

;Excellent works can maintain an excellent balance in grasping female narratives and social and cultural landscapes. Let’s not mention the classic representative works of the fourth and fifth generation directors, such as "Qiu Ju's Lawsuit", "The Love of Humans and Ghosts", "The Beginning of Spring", etc.

;

;Here is an example of an unpopular masterpiece - "The Crying Woman". The director and screenwriter of this film, Liu Bingjian, used the story of Wang Guixiang, a Guizhou woman who made money through mourning, to show the public that China has a long history of funeral culture.

;

;;

;

;Among them, Wang Guixiang Her strong vitality, her shrewd and kind feminine charm, and the warmth and warmth of people in rural society can all leave a deep impression on people. "Stone Gate", which failed to do this, also formed a contradiction, with its novel subject matter but bland plot.

;

;However, it is worth mentioning that "Stone Gate" is almost the same as a documentary in terms of realism. It is a story that grows out of the shooting environment and the actors' performance.

;

;The actors who play Lin Sen’s parents are director Huang Ji’s biological parents. They run this clinic in reality, and their home is also the real residence of the director and his wife.

;

;;

;

;This movie Filmed over a ten-month period following the pregnancy cycle, and with a limited budget, it didn't have a set designed in advance like many films, and the actors were thrown directly into real space. ‍‍‍‍‍

;

;Changsha is the main filming location. The lens captures its glamorous and prosperous side, as well as its chaotic and dark corners.

;

;;

;

;‍‍In addition to the director The camera strives to be close to reality, and also tries its best to show the living conditions of girls in non-developed areas. ‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍

;

;The original setting of the heroine Lin Sen was an imaginary image of a proactive female college student. But this was completely different from the state of actor Yao Honggui at the time, and it was also different from the current situation of many young college students.

;

;The director and his wife rewrote the character design, and the protagonist’s story is a mixed experience of female college students obtained from interviews.

;

;Through the unexpected pregnancy experience of a small town girl, the film reflects the structural dilemma of this group. It originates from many constraints such as patriarchy, commodity society, and power class.

;

;;

;

;The heroine was The oppression does not occur openly, but it does not mean that multiple exploitation does not exist. This complex structural dilemma creates a low margin for error in women’s choices.

;

;For example, it seems that Lin Sen can make different choices, take the initiative to have an abortion, not pay off the debt for his mother, or give birth to a child and raise him, but no life path will become easier.

;

;Because there are too many stone doors in her life that are difficult to push open, and she can only avoid falling by climbing hard.

;

;;

;

;The ending of the film It is open-ended, and we have no way of knowing the final fate of the child.

;

;What the audience can see is that the male employer hopes to postpone the adoption date due to the epidemic. The heroine Lin Sen, who is waiting for the handover, was triggered by the child's cry and got chest pain and got out of the car.

;

;But it hurts and there is no escape. Escape, the pain is still there.

;

;The lack of hope in her life made her breathless. However, instead of floating helplessly in the ocean of life, it is better to fight hard and push open the stone door to try to welcome new life.

;

;Recently, a piece of news about "Shanghai police came to arrest German Shepherd" triggered a "storm in a teacup" ".

;

;It was first reported online that on October 24, the police from Wusong District, Shanghai came to the door and seized a 16-year-old German shepherd. The owner surrenders the dog. In the videos and texts circulating on the Internet, the dog has become a "retired police dog" or even a "retired military dog." The words "18 special police officers in three vehicles broke down the door and caught a 16-year-old dying old dog". Hot search.

;

;On October 24, the Shanghai Wusong Subdistrict Office issued a notice on this matter. The report stated that a resident of Haibin San Village was raising large and aggressive dogs (wolfdogs with hybrid blood) without a license, and had repeatedly walked dogs without leashes and large dogs without muzzles and other illegal dog-raising behaviors. After receiving reports from surrounding residents, police officers from the police station, staff from the Dog Breeding Office, comprehensive law enforcement officials and the district's special police detachment jointly came to rectify the situation. The dog owner took the initiative to open the door and cooperated with the work, and took the initiative to hand over the dog to the relevant departments for containment and disposal.

;

;After careful review of this incident, there are many contradictions and inconsistencies between the information transmitted online and the official report. Even after the report was released, many people expressed "disbelief" and need to be analyzed one by one.

;

;First of all, the "identity" and "bloodline" of the dog involved. Someone on Weibo said it was a retired police dog, but the "uniform" in the video posted online only had "POLICE" in English and no Chinese "police dog". This is obviously inconsistent with the "standard dress" of domestic police dogs.

;

;Public information shows that the first batch of retired police dogs in Shanghai were opened for adoption on September 5, 2022. The eight police dogs announced at that time were all from the police dog training base of the Songjiang Branch of the Shanghai Public Security Bureau. Bradford, Malinois, Rottweiler, Springer Spaniel, German Shepherd, Doberman, etc., but only one Springer Spaniel and two Labradors are open to the public for adoption, and the remaining five including the German Shepherd are retired Police dogs can only be adopted by units. At the same time, adoptive citizens also need to receive follow-up visits every three months.

;

;In other words, there is indeed a German Shepherd among the retired police dogs open for adoption in Shanghai, but it was not given to citizens for adoption. Therefore, the rumors that the dogs involved were just "retired police dogs" and "German shepherds" are self-defeating.

;

;As for the "retired military dog" theory, there is a lack of any supporting information, and it directly conflicts with the "POLICE uniform" in the online video. China's "Interim Regulations on the Work of Military Dogs" defines military dogs as special combatants and an integral part of the military's combat effectiveness. After military dogs retire, they will generally enter military dog ​​breeding and training bases to "live out their old age". Military dogs with meritorious service will also enjoy recuperation treatment. Even if adoption is open, adopters have very high requirements, including "must love dogs", "must have experience raising large dogs", and "cannot be a living environment in an urban community". Some units will also require adopters to have Military personnel will vouch for them, and they must have a stable income.

;

;In the "Zhengzhou 10 million reward for finding retired military dogs" incident on July 9, 2023, the "retired military dog" gimmick instantly proved that this is a "starting picture, the rest are all It’s fake news, because the description in the “reward notice” is completely contrary to the regulations for the adoption of retired military dogs. In this incident, the terms "retired police dog" and "retired military dog" are inconsistent and can be proven to be pure rumors.

;

;Secondly, whether the dog owner’s dog-raising behavior is legal and compliant, and the truth behind the door-to-door rectification actions.

;

;Article 12, paragraph 3, of the "Shanghai Dog Breeding Management Regulations" passed in 2011 and revised in 2016, prohibits individuals from raising aggressive dogs. Violators of this provision will have the aggressive dogs taken into custody by the public security department. The "Shanghai Catalog of Prohibited Individual Breeding of Violent Dogs" stipulates 24 types of ferocious dogs, including German Shepherds, French Wolfdogs, and Kunming Wolfdogs. Therefore, whether the owner of the dog involved adopts a German shepherd or a hybrid wolfdog, it is undoubtedly a violent dog breed that is prohibited from personal breeding, and dog registration, annual inspection and dog management fees are out of the question.

;

;Judging from the official report, the owner of the dog involved also engaged in illegal dog-raising behaviors such as walking the dog without a leash and without wearing a muzzle. This is also consistent with the "20 reports from surrounding residents" in the online information. The statement is consistent. Articles 21 and 30 of the "Shanghai Dog Breeding Management Regulations" also clearly stipulate that dog owners shall abide by public order and shall not interfere with the normal lives of others. Residents' committees also have the right to formulate and supervise dog breeding conventions or regulations in their residential areas. Management, dog owners should comply.

;

;Now that the illegal dog-raising behavior of the dog owner involved has been confirmed, surrounding residents naturally have the right to report and request the public security department to take in the dog. This request is reasonable and reasonable, and the joint door-to-door rectification by various local departments is also in line with current laws and regulations. Judging from the live videos and pictures, "18 special police officers" is also false information, and relevant social media bloggers have deliberately exaggerated it.

;

;Finally, this incident also shows that relevant public issues have lost focus, which may not be a blessing to the public interest. Faced with the public issue of "how to regulate dog ownership," some people are willing to mobilize by creating fake news and create traffic and attention with "tragic narratives." Similar behavior is no longer a public discussion, but an out-and-out "information war" and "public opinion war" method, trying to blur the focus and muddy the water.

;

;In fact, laws and regulations regulating dog breeding have been implemented in various places for many years, in order to better protect people's rights. Dogs are not civil subjects and are the private property of their owners. "Conflict between humans and dogs" is a false issue that does not exist. The real issue is how to regulate dog breeding: only when the premise of protecting human rights is established can we talk about protecting people's property rights to dogs. Protecting people from being hurt by dogs and preventing "dog bites" should still be a real issue that public opinion pays attention to.
